dialogues.speaker: THESSALY THACKER
dialogues.text: I’m sure she was. That cow. She couldn't find a new story if it were taped to her posterior.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Well, she’s—

dialogues.speaker: THESSALY THACKER
dialogues.text: High ankle sprain? That’s the best you could come up with? We all know about the drinking jags and the womanizing and the trips to San Bernardino.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Baird is a good family man. He has a high ankle sprain. YOUNG MAN’S VOICE Mr. Mannix! A freckled youth in a cardigan sweater is bicycling up th walkway. As he furiously pedals, a Capitol Pictures penna snaps and flutters from a high antenna off the back fende He skids to a halt, close.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What’s up, Peanut?

dialogues.speaker: PEANUT
dialogues.text: Natalie told me to find you PDQ! I know it sounds screwy but she said someone's calling from the future!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: The—good lord! Thessaly, I have to run.

dialogues.speaker: THESSALY THACKER
dialogues.text: If you do know where Baird is, let me talk to him. Eddie Mannix is already hastening off.  60.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Sure—well, I’'1l—find out where he is, right away, Thessaly, I’m sure he’11— (turns with a thought) Say, what kind of name is Thessaly, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: THESSALY THACKER
dialogues.text: It’s a name that twenty million readers trust. They want the truth, Eddie. On his hasty retreat:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Truth, yes! We're gonna give it to'm!. He jogs off with the bulging attaché case clamped to his side, led by Peanut on his bicycle with its fluttering pennant. INT. EDDIE’S OUTER OFFICE - DAY Eddie strides through the outer office.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: On two! And Hobie Doyle is in there.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: INNER OFFICE
dialogues.text: Hobie, in dinner jacket, rises from the chair facing the desk.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Lo, Mr. Mannix. As he rushes around the desk to the phone and puts down attaché case:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming, Hobie, one second. Mannix here, who—Damn! He looks at the handset he has picked up, shakes his head cradles it. He hits a button on the phone.  61. .-+. Hung up, Natalie. Tell me the second they call back.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Eddie looks darkly down at the attaché case.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: ‘T’s goin’ on there, Mr. Mannix, looks like you're expectin’ rain.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Nah, it’s—nothing. How’s the first day on the picture? Getting comfortable? Eddie is still looking down at the bulging attaché case. pushes experimentally down on the middle of its buldge. H pops the clasps. He redistributes the currency inside—blocked from Hobie’s view by the case itself—as Hobie talks.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I guess it’s goin’ purt good, that Mr. Lau—er, Laurentz, he’s an awful good man he’s helpin me get through it, I give him all the credit in the world, me the new hand in the bunkhouse, they got me talkin; a lot which takes a little gettin’ use to, talkin’ with the camera lookin’ at me but heck I enjoy.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Good, that’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Usually on a picture I just say “Whitey!” Or “Whoa, there,” but this-here it’s talkin’ an’t’s people listenin’, threw me little at first but I think I got my leg up onner now. Eddie has closed the case again and does the clasps. He assesses its shape as he talks to Hobie:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Well that’s fine. Laurence came in this morning to tell me how well you're doing, he’s very impressed. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You just continue to do whatever he says. He knows how to make a quality picture.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Oh that is true, he will not quit on a take until it has quality— The phone buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Hang on, Hobie. (punches the intercom button) That them? NATALIE’S VOICE Sorry, sir—no, do you want Mrs. Mannix on one? He deflates; picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Hi hon... Oh, you know—busy... Uh- huh... Uh-huh... But I thought he asked to play infield... I see... Well, maybe we should make him honor that commitment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has reopened the case and is rearranging the money. .-- Well that’s true—Of course, you're right. Okay, okay, I’1l call the coach... Sure. Love you too. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Mannix, should I run out’n get you a bigger grip? That’n looks a little snug. Eddie looks up at Hobie and focuses on him for the first time. A long, appraising look. Hobie returns the look, not sure what it means. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Hobie: there’s a hundred thousand dollars in that attaché case. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ransom money. Baird Whitlock has been kidnapped. Hobie stares, shocked. Eddie Mannix nods a grim confirmat Finally:

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Well, this is bad. Bad for movie stars ever’where. Eddie’s mouth forms a moue of agreement.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you got no idea who’s mixed up in this thang? Eddie gives a wagging headshake.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I would look at the extries.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: The extras. Why?

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Well you just never know about an extrie. They come’n go. Everyone else, I’m on the set, I look at the guy settin’ the 5K I think, “Why there’s old Bud, settin the 5K.” Script girl, wrangler, same thang. Extries, that’s diffurnt. Not makin’ a blanket call here—there’s good extries’n bad extries. All I’m sayin: you look at an extrie, you got no idea what he’s thankin’. Eddie stares at Hobie, contemplating. The silence is broken by the buzz of his phone. Natalie’s voice comes through the unit: NATALIE’S VOICE He’s back—line one.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Hello!... Yes, I have it... Stage 8?... Right. Just leave it there? And when do I get Baird?... I’1l do it right now. He hangs up, looks at the case, looks at Hobie.  64. Can I use your belt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are coming off the lettering on the side of a boat whi identifies it as “The Swingin’ Dinghy.” Our move reveals that behind the boat which is suspended two chains like a lifeboat is a backbar in the middle of which is a clock, just now striking twelve. We move down the clock to find a bartender looking up at it. A dishrag draped over his shoulder, a well-chewed cigar stub is pla in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: The Swingin’ Dinghy is closin’, folks. Time for me to clean up, time for you to clear out. He moves to get a broom. On his move we widen out to show bar's clientele: about a dozen sailors and their dates, f or six young women. The boat of which this establishment namesake is a quarter-size model hanging over the bar. The girls are mounting the stairs to leave the cellar bar One turns back with a farewell:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: So long, fellas! See ya in eight months! The morose sailors all gaze up at the departing girls. Th bartender asks one sailor:

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Eight months? He is addressing a sailor whose glum look stays on the exiting girls. The look lingers on the door after it clos behind them. The sailor sighs.

dialogues.speaker: SAILOR
dialogues.text: Yeah—we're shippin’ out in the mawnin. Another sailor, seated on the stool of a piano near the stairs, is also looking glum.

dialogues.speaker: SAILOR 2
dialogues.text: Golly: eight months without a dame. The lead sailor, equally downcast, is played by Burt Gurn  65.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Can ya beat it.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (gruff) Yer gonna have to beat it. Visible through a high window-well which gives onto the sidewalk are the gams of a girl who has stopped to adjust seam of one stocking. Burt, gazing yearningly up at the legs, starts to sing:

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Oh, we’re headin’ out to sea... The production number “No Dames!” begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song has developed and the dance begun, but here, off set, the blaring playback is echoing and not as loud. Edd Mannix enters the stage. He is dimly lit only by spill fr the bar set, house lights turned off for shooting. Eddie gives cautious looks around as he hoists the attach case, now secured around its middle by a shiny black belt gingerly stows the attaché case behind an electrical box bearing the warning, DANGER! HIGH VOLTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE SET
dialogues.text: The song finishes with Burt being ass-bounced and the bartender bellowing:

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Now cut that out! This ain’t that kind of place! The general pandemonium of the dancing sailors is arreste a voice through a megaphone:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: And... cut! Yah, okay. Okay. We cut behind the director seated on a canvas chair onto back of which his name is stitched: “Arne Seslum.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, Burt Gurney. We go again.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: All right, kids, back to one! 66. Burt Gurney walks up, boyishly cheerful, and is joined by Bartender.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Anything different, Mr. Seslum?

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: Yah yah yah, no no no, mostly pretty good. But this time, don’t put dishrag on bartender’s head. You're the star of the picture, Burt Gurney. Who cares about the bartender, you are the star. The Bartender grumbles, walking away:

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: That’s my whole character, the slow burn.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: (genuine) Gosh, Mr. Seslum, I don’t mind, if he wants me to—

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: It is decided! Eddie Mannix walks up.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Lo, Burt. Brightly, before heading back to the set:

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Mannix!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Arne, I don’t want to stick my nose in other people’s business, but, uh, I understand you’ve been, uh, associating with DeeAnna Moran?

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: Yah yah we associated.  67.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yes, and she’s—

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: But no more. No more. Don’t you worry, Eddie Mannix.

dialogues.speaker: . EDDIE
dialogues.text: But Arne, you are aware that she’s, uh—

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: This must not be in movie magazines, that we associated.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No, of course not—

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: My wife cannot read this.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Your—excuse me? Arne fishes out a wallet.

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: Ilsa Pflug.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Ilsa...? Arne shows him a picture of himself and a plump woman wit braids.

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: Ilsa Pflug-Seslum. In Malmo.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I was not aware of that. Arne flips through, showing more pictures: himself skiing the family posed together in cable sweaters.

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: Yah, yah, two children.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (sotto) Third on the way, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: Do you have physical culture, Eddie Mannix? Do you ski?  68.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No, I, uh, never took it up. Seems like a lot of fun.

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: Yah, fresh air. (thumps himself on chest) Air in— (he sucks in) Out— (he blows out) Lungs. Breathe. (takes back the wallet) I no more associate with DeeAnna Moran—it is decided!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh— Something on the set, past Eddie’s shoulder, draws Arne’s furious look.

dialogues.speaker: ARNE
dialogues.text: NO, no, no, don’t swing your arms like hairy ape! This is not fat stupid people, this is Arne Seslum production!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raucous male laughter hits the cut. The men are emerging the hall into the main room, Baird and Herman in the lead Baird's arm draped companionably over Herman’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: So I feel someone poking me and I wake up and it’s Clark and he says, "Well, her keys weren't in there so I guess we're walkin’!” Roaring laughter from the Communists.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This was back before Gable was Gable. The men make themselves comfortable in the living room wi its view of the crashing surf. It is now late day; a red hangs beyond the jagged rocks at the mouth of the cove. Baird is lost in misty reminiscence:  69.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We used to go to San Berdoo every weekend, Bob Stack would come sometimes, the Blue Grotto was still open—Dave Chasen was a busboy... (the dramatic view finally registers) Quite a place! Yours?

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, gracious no. It belongs to a member of our study group. He couldn’t be here this afternoon—he’1l be sad to have missed you. He’s a fan.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Uh-huh, that’s swell. So I black out, wake up here and I’m thinking, Baird, you have got to stop doing this! (laughter) But you’re saying, actually, technically I’ve been... kidnapped. Again, agreeable laughter from the Communists. Herman smi as well.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: Well, technically, yes.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: And there’s gonna be a ransom.

dialogues.speaker: BENEDICT
dialogues.text: I'd hardly call it “ransom.” Herman indicates the speaker.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: Benedict there—that’s Benedict de Bonaventure—wrote “The House of Ahasuaris.” A low whistle from Baird. Herman nods.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes. Enormous hit, made the studio millions of dollars. Did you see any of those millions of dollars, Ben?  70.

dialogues.speaker: BENEDICT
dialogues.text: I did not.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: Dutch over there—Dutch Zweistrong—wrote “All The Way To Uruguay.”

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: (testy) I wrote all the “All The Way” pictures.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: All successful. You see any of the profits, Dutch? Dutch gives a short barking laugh.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All of us here are writers. The pictures originated with us, they're our ideas, but they’re owned by the studio. I’m not saying only writers are being exploited—tI mean, look at yourself, Baird.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Oh, you know—the studio takes care of me.

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY MAN
dialogues.text: What’re you, a child?

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: (apology for the bad manners ) I think what Herschel’s trying to say is, just because the studio owns the means of production, why should it be able to take the money—our money, the value created by our labor—and dole out what it pleases? That’s not right. So—no. No, I wouldn’t call it “ransom.”

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Payback.

dialogues.speaker: FOURTH MAN
dialogues.text: Partial payback.  71.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: Now, until quite recently our study group had a narrow focus. We concentrated on getting Communist content into motion pictures—always in a sub rosa way, of course. And we've been pretty darn successful. You remember, in “Kerner’s Corner”—the Town Hall scene, where the aldermen overturn the rotten election and make Gus the mayor?

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: (getting it, nodding) Oh! Yeah. Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: I like to think we’ve changed a few minds. But then—well, Dr. Marcuse came down from Stanford, joined the study group. And started teaching us about direct action. Praxis. Action. Faintly gesturing with his pipe:

dialogues.speaker: DR. MARCUSE
dialogues.text: We each pursue our own economic interest—we ourselves are not above the laws of history. But in pursuing our interest with vigor, we accelerate the dialectic, and hasten the end of history and the creation of the New Man.

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY MAN
dialogues.text: Plus, we make a little dough.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: Shutup! We're not even talking about money; we're talking about economics.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Sure. Good. Good stuff. So—do I get a share of the ransom? Chuckles all around. Herman gives a weak smile.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: Well—no, Mr. Whitlock. You could hardly share in your own ransom. That would be unethical.  72.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know if that’s fair, fellas! The whole set-up only works if I play along, right, if I don’t let on I know who kidnapped me?

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: So what if I don’t play along? What if I named names? The smiling faces around him harden. Baird, committed, plows on:

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «+. Just... told the truth? The alienation is palpable. Herman alone seems unruffled:

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t think you'll do that, Mr. Whitlock. What if we told the truth, about—”On Wings as Eagles?” Baird instantly sobers. He looks up at the men around him, their faces set. He lo at Herman, the one person still smiling. INT. SID SIEGELSTEIN’S OFFICE - DAY Eddie Mannix arrives to lean against his door jamb. The l bullpen, rows of decks, is at his back.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Sid, we have to work something out for DeeAnna Moran. Sid looks up from his paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: She get married again?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No, that’s the problem. Having a child, not married. A whistle from Sid.  73.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: Tough.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. No father. Well, of course there is one, somewhere... He waves airily. Sid nods understanding.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: But who knows...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Exactly. So is there any way she—I’m just spitballing here—any way she could adopt her own child? Sid gazes at Eddie. His look drifts off.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: Interesting... As a single...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Mm, she disappears for a while, reappears—

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: —and she wants to share her blessings—adopt a child.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: Sure, she’s always yearned to be a mother...

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t see why not. Nothing in California statute that prohibits adoption by one’s own parent.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: This is new ground here. Technically, she’d have to give up the baby, in order to adopt it, to a third... party—  74.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Joe Silverman. Natalie, with clipboard, approaches from the background.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: Joe Silverman, exactly. He’s the foster father for a few days. She hands the kid to Joe, he hands it back... I’1l do some research. (taps his desktop) This is exciting.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Mannix, it’s five-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a very late day. Eddie Mannix strides through the campus with Natalie trailing.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: —and asked all the assistant directors. One of them said that an extra in the courtyard-of-Sestimus-— Amydias scene seemed jumpy.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: All right, get Walt the name of the the extra so he can bring him in and sweat him. Walt should tell him we won’t press charges if he tells us where Baird’s been taken.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: If he plays dumb—or if the A.D.’s wrong and he is dumb—check the other extras.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Check. Thessaly Thacker called, said you promised her an interview with Baird today. Check that, it was Thora Thacker.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No, it was Thessaly. Tell her he was at the doctor longer than expected, she can see him on the set bright and early tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check. And is that last part true?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Let’s hope so. That reminds me: I need a list of everyone who worked on “On Wings as Eagles” who’s still at the studio.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: “On Wings as Eagles”—that’s a while ago, now. Aside from Baird and the director it won’t be a long list.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh, get it for me. That it?

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: One more thing: a Mr. Cuddahy called, said you know him.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah. They are mounting a set of steps leading to a long walkwa with many doors spaced at short and regular intervals.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Said it’s urgent he see you one last time. Suggested same place, seven this evening.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What?! Why? Never mind. (checks watch) Tell him I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bangs through a door: Cc. C. CALHOUN

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: A stout middle-aged woman is at work at a clattering upri moviola. A cigarette plumes in one hand. The room is laye with stale smoke.  76.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Hello, C.C. The woman spins around in her castored chair and the chai creaks as she tips her body back so as to aim her face at Eddie. Her thinkc glasses make her eyes float hugely befo her face. The eyes blink. Her voice is emphysemic: c.C. Hello, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Wanna lace up what you have on “Merrily We Dance”? c.C. Just working on it now. I’1l slap on a little music. C.C. brakes the picture, rolls to a trim bin, pulls track from a pin, flanges it on the side of the moviola and the lays it under a sound head. She snaps down the head and r the movie forward. Eddie leans in to look at the picture cube. Glow from the moviola screen underlights Eddie’s face. A fanfare. On the screen, a card:

dialogues.speaker: LAURENCE LAURENTZ PRESENTS
dialogues.text: Grease-marks on the print form a V that indicates a fade down. As waltz music comes up, an inverted V grease-mark indica a fade up on a shot of the dancing feet of many people, g swirling, tuxedoed legs debonairly stepping. Supered on the shot:

dialogues.speaker: MERRILY WE DANCE
dialogues.text: Another fade-down mark. Lateral track on the feet of a man and a woman, crossing city sidewalk. The man's feet hurry out of frame as we he him call “Taxi!”  77. The woman's feet continue on to bring into frame, when sh reaches the curb, the bottom of a cab door being opened f her by the man. As she climbs into the cab we match cut into: The back of the cab. The pretty young woman slides over s that a caddish looking young man can sit in as well. The starts into motion.

dialogues.speaker: CAD
dialogues.text: Back to your place?

dialogues.speaker: ALLEGRA
dialogues.text: Oh, what a bore. I rather thought we might go to Lake Onondega for the weekend, just the two of us.

dialogues.speaker: CAD
dialogues.text: Don't have my valise—I left it in your foyer.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEGRA
dialogues.text: (sly) You'll get by without a change.

dialogues.speaker: CAD
dialogues.text: (wolf) Suits me. If you don't mind skipping out on your own party, Allegra.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEGRA
dialogues.text: Suits me.

dialogues.speaker: CAD
dialogues.text: (meaningful) And skipping out on Monty.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEGRA
dialogues.text: (smile) That suits me as well. The man laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CAD
dialogues.text: Poor Monty.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEGRA
dialogues.text: What Monty doesn’t know...

dialogues.speaker: CAD
dialogues.text: «.. won’t hurt Monty.  78.

dialogues.speaker: SWELL APARTMENT INTERIOR
dialogues.text: Lateral track on a pair of feet: a man walking down a hallway. As he enters a foyer he comes up short, feet tur halfway toward a valise that has been left under a table. After a considering beat he proceeds on, and we pan his f to a door which he opens. A match cut around the other side of the door onto the pe entering, who is now revealed to be—Hobie Doyle. We are n in the scene we saw being shot.

dialogues.speaker: DIERDRE
dialogues.text: Oh Monty! Come join me on the divaaaaa... As Dierdre beckons Monty her motion slows, and her slowin speech becomes basso before lapsing to quiet and the ratcheting noise of the machine also falls quiet and we a looking at a frozen frame that slowly discolors at the center. The discoloration starts to spread outward as the frame burns. Eddie looks quizzically at the stalled picture. A rasping voice: c.C. Reversh. Eddie looks and reacts with a modest but definite take at C.C. bent double in her chair, the side of her face press snugly to the moviola near the gearing for the sound roll The side of her face is squashed flat against the machine something cinches the folds of fat at her neck. She is be strangled. C.Cc. (CONT'D) Reversh. Eddie looks helplessly at the machine. C.Cc. (CONT'D) Reversh. Eddie casts frantically about, locates the forward/revers switch, flips it. The soundtrack grinds into motion, in reverse. The pictur plays likewise.  79. As the sound relays feed out her scarf, C.C. has increasi play such that she may slowly draw her head away from the machine. When she is completely free she hits the handbrake, stopp the film. C.Cc. (CONT'D) Shouldn’t wear scarves. She sucks greedily at a cigarette. She flips the reverse switch and the film rolls forward again. Hobie once again enters, looking very dashing in his tux.

dialogues.speaker: DIERDRE
dialogues.text: Oh Monty! Come join me on the divan. The discolored frame flashes by and Monty sits into a brooding close shot on the divan.

dialogues.speaker: DIERDRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It seems Allegra's a no-show, which is simply a bore, but I can partner you in bridge. (reacting to him) Why the pout? A hold on Hobie as he frames a haunted answer. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: It's... complicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gong stings the cut to pushing in to Arthur Fung as he gives a short bow.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR FUNG
dialogues.text: How pleasant to see you again, Mr. Manni— SPLASH! A push through the curtain of beads to see Mr. Cuddahy, looking up from his booth, a drink with an umbre in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: CUDDAHY
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming back, Mannix.  80.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CUDDAHY
dialogues.text: (chuckling) You're taking us down to the wire, aren’t ya?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It’s not a ploy—just a big decision.

dialogues.speaker: CUDDAHY
dialogues.text: Absolutely! No foul. But the board was concerned when I couldn’t give ‘em a yes this afternoon, and they've authorized me to say this. You sign on, your term of contract is ten years. Eddie gives a low whistle. Cuddahy nods. Yeah. You get it, right? That means your stock options are guaranteed to vest. You’d never have to work again if you chose to retire after your term. Think about it: lifetime employment; you wouldn’t be a glorified working stiff like you are now. And you'll be running a business, not a circus. Drink? (notices Eddie's look) Cigarette? Cuddahy proffers the pack which Eddie has been eyeing. Ed hesitates, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No, no I—TI have to run, I, I should talk this over with my wife—

dialogues.speaker: CUDDAHY
dialogues.text: Course you should. Talk it over, think about your family, let us know in the morning. Oh! (grinning, produces two packages ) Now, if you think this is a bribe, you're absolutely right. Two kids, right, boy and a girl? They love this stuff. Used to be trains.  81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glowing in the early evening. Reverse on its drive. Hobie Doyle leans against a parked with his arms folded, waiting, gazing at the mansion. A l still beat, and then he abruptly sflffs a bunch of sunflo shells out of his mouth. He gazes idly around. He has a thought. He opens the back door of the limo and takes out a length rope. He starts twirling, creating a nice big loop. He expertly tips his wrist to make the loop spin level with the groun a height of half a foot. He hops in and out of the loop.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello Hobie. Startled, he muffs a hop-out and the rope dies against hi shins.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Oh hello Carlotta.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOTTA
dialogues.text: Am I late? He coils the rope.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Aw no it ain’t nothin’. Thanks an awful bunch for goin’ to this picture with me, I don’t know if you like livestock but I think it’s got moments I really do. You look var purty.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOTTA
dialogues.text: Well, thank you, Hobie. I’m sure I'll like the picture—I like all of your pictures.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Well I like yours too, they are just the craziest things. Is it hard to dance with all them bananas on your head?  82. She plants her purse on her head as she demonstrates a rh move:

dialogues.speaker: CARLOTTA
dialogues.text: Oh no, anyone can do it, is all inna hips anna-lips anna-eyes anna- thighs! She finishes with a kick and a head-tip that launches the purse backwards off her head to be grabbed by one hand be her back. INT. MANNIX’S KIDS’ BEDROOM - NIGHT We hear a door opening and hallway light fans onto an adorable little girl asleep in bed. Eddie looks down at her, smiles, stoops to adjust the dol she holds against her face. He rises to gaze down for ano beat, then moves. The opposite bed: an adorable little boy. Eddie eases the askew coonskin cap off of the boy, stands looking down. Top of the boy’s wardrobe. Baseball pennants are on the w behind it. Eddie’s hands enter to place a soaring airplan a peg on a pedestal. Top of the girl’s wardrobe. Dolls are seated on it leanin against the wall. Eddie’s hands enter to place a folded maroon uniform, and, on top of the uniform, a maroon cap “Stewardess” stiched in gold. INT. MANNIX’S KITCHEN - NIGHT Eddie is at a plateful of dinner. His wife bustles as he eats.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MANNIX
dialogues.text: Little Eddie wanted me to tell you about his baseball game. They won.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: That’s terrific. Gosh, I never called the coach! Eddie played at shortstop?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MANNIX
dialogues.text: Mm, and he did so well he wants to stay there now.  83.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Great, it took care of itself.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MANNIX
dialogues.text: And Darlene did very well on her Spanish test.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: That’s good, she was worried about that. Thanks for heating up the roast.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MANNIX
dialogues.text: Warm glass of milk?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No, thanks hon—coffee. Gotta run back to the studio, a few things to take care of.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MANNIX
dialogues.text: Gee, another late night. Eddie is ruminative:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Mm. You know... Lockheed improved their offer. Darned good money. And the hours wouldn’t be crazy like this, either.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MANNIX
dialogues.text: It’s nice to be wanted.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, but—what do you think? They wanna know tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MANNIX
dialogues.text: I like the shorter hours. But what do you think, honey? You know best. Nodding, chewing, thinking:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MANNIX
dialogues.text: How’s it going with the smoking, dear? Eddie is startled out of his ruminations:  84.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Oh, you know... INT. EDDIE’S PACKARD - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE IN HIS PACKARD
dialogues.text: He drives, squinting against oncoming headlights. The plummy-voiced narrator:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE-OVER
dialogues.text: The denizens of the great city make ready for nightlife—or for sleep. But Eddie Mannix will have neither...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Familiar shot from high on the bluff down on the octahedr house, now glowing with internal light. The ocean is no m than glittering highlights caught from the moon.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE-OVER
dialogues.text: Even in westerly Malibu the sun has moved on, leaving the vast and tireless sea to heave itself blindly upon the shore.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: We are in the living room which, it being night, offers n more view. The writers sit playing at cards, smoking, see to make time pass. A man circles the table dropping a pair of gloves next to each card player—fingerless gloves with leather grips, as for golfing. The card players little notice the deposit o gloves at their places.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE-OVER
dialogues.text: Baird Whitlock has become an acolyte of the Communists, a convert to their cause, his belief compelled but not grudging—no more than was Saul’s on the dusty road of long ago. He now seeks to learn more from the leader from the north...  85. Baird is indeed sitting with Professor Marcuse, who is ju finishing talking as their conversation mixes up, with Ba nodding vigorous concurrence. VOICE-OVER (CONT’D) -.. and becomes ever more committed to the quest to hasten an end to history and bring on—the New Man!

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Herb—Herb!—That’s exactly what I was talking about, that’s what happened when I went to Reno with Danny Kaye and he asked me to shave his back! Exact same thing! Because I'm thinking—who benefits? Also, I gotta tell ya, everyone thinks Danny is a jerk but he’s not really a jerk, it’s just the theory generating its own anti-theory... Professor Marcuse’s brow furrows as he tries to follow Baird’s point. ... So there we are, me and Danny, and I’m wondering what the hell I’m doing with this razor and he says it’s for a part in a Norman Taurog picture but Judy Canova is there and she knows Norman and she says Danny’s not doing a Norman Taurog picture—he just wants you to shave his back! And that’s who benefits! INT. GRAUMAN’S CHINESE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: A LOBBY CARD
dialogues.text: It is for “Lazy Ol’ Moon,” starring Hobie Doyle. When it wiped by a foreground cross we cut wider: The near-empty lobby of a grand theater. A latecoming gentleman and his wife are opening the auditorium door to enter, the movie’s soundtrack fanning up as they do so.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE-OVER
dialogues.text: In livelier precincts, the swells of Dreamland gather to inspect the complicated weave of another piece of gossamer...  86.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Hobie and Carlotta are watching the movie.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE-OVER
dialogues.text: «+. Another movie, another portion of balm for the ache of a toiling mankind. Hobie leans in to Carlotta.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Don’t know ‘bout this part, they only gimme one shot at the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is evening. A pretty young woman converses through a cookhouse window with a grizzled old man in the yard. The man—Curly—wears the union suit and the bent-back hatbrim a Western sidekick. Someone offscreen is lazily chording a guitar.

dialogues.speaker: CURLY
dialogues.text: It wasn't my fault you saw me take the pie off the sill Miz McGraw.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Not your fault! Whose fault was it, Curly?

dialogues.speaker: CURLY
dialogues.text: Why, that crazy full moon! Two weeks ago you'd a never seen me take it! Laughter from the audience as Curly stomps over to the ma playing guitar: Hobie, relaxing on a tipped-back chair on bunkhouse porch.

dialogues.speaker: CURLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Durn that moon! What good is she anyhow! Wish there never was no moon! Wish there warn't no bossy old women!

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Don’t blame that moon, Curly. She can’t do nothin’ but shine!  87. The guitar intro has ended and Hobie launches into the fi verse of “Lazy O1' Moon.” He looks up at the moon, occasionally looks back to the pretty woman in the window listens, smiling. As the verse ends we cut to Curly elsewhere in the yard, looking angrily down at something off:

dialogues.speaker: CURLY
dialogues.text: Durn you! You turned Curly Strimlin over to the authorities for the last time! We cut over his shoulder: he is addressing a reflection o the moon in a watering trough. He now dives in with hands outstretched as if to throttle the reflection. Hobie sings on. Curly sits up in the trough sputtering an looks around, stymied and irate.

dialogues.speaker: CURLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Durn! Where'd she go?! Roaring laughter from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie Mannix pulls up in his Packard. It is late night; t street is deserted except for one swank parked car, a cre colored luxury sedan, that stands out on this less-than-s street. The car’s uniformed driver leans against the hood smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wooden stairway. On the risers are painted the names of building’s business tenants. Eddie Mannix trudges up the stairs in fedora and trenchcoat with collar turned up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is lined by doors with transom windows. Lettering on t pebbled glass of each office door identifies its occupant One office only shows light from inside:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. JOE SILVERMAN’S OFFICE - NIGHT Eddie taps at the door. It is opened by Sid Sieglestein, the studio lawyer. An in office door, standing open, shows Joe Silverman sitting a his desk; mid-thirties and, like his office, low-rent but neat and utterly without character. DeeAnna Moran sits across from him in a cream-colored dre that matches her car outside, and a black hat and veil. S has a cigarette in one hand and with the other signs a document in multiple places as Joe, leaning across the de turns pages and points.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: We just got started—I’ve been taking DeeAnna through this. They are joining the two in the inner office, Sid now addressing DeeAnna. «+. So Joseph has done—well, just a whole lot of good work for us in the past. Whenever we’ve needed a witness or a third party for, I don’t know—a petition of grievance or alienation of affection. DeeAnna sneaks looks at Joe as she signs pages.

dialogues.speaker: DEEANNA
dialogues.text: And he’s reliable? The man shows no resentment of the question and indeed no affect at all:

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’m bonded, miss.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: Joe is the most reliable human being on the planet, in our experience. When Chubby Cregar was intoxicated and hit a pedestrian on Gower, we had his vehicle title transferred to Joe’s name and Joe did six months in the LA County lock-up.

dialogues.speaker: DEEANNA
dialogues.text: But you’re off the sauce now?  89.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I never touch it, miss. It was a legal fiction.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: That's exactly right. When the studio needs somebody who meets the legal standard of, uh—how did you put it, Sid?

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: Personhood.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Joe steps in and acts as the, uh... person.

dialogues.speaker: DEEANNA
dialogues.text: So you're a professional—person?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's right, miss. And initial here, and here.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: Joe will be the foster parent until such time as you adopt the child, which you can do as soon as Joe takes possession of it.

dialogues.speaker: DEEANNA
dialogues.text: And he’s reliable?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I’m bonded, miss.

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: The release papers you're signing are not public record. All these documents remain sealed until the year two thousand and fifteen. Joe takes the document and slides its last page into an embosser and squeezes.

dialogues.speaker: DEEANNA
dialogues.text: No one the wiser?

dialogues.speaker: SID
dialogues.text: No one the wiser. No fans, no court officials—not even a notary public.  90.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Joe himself is the notary. DeeAnna examines Joe who is tensed, squeezing with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: DEEANNA
dialogues.text: You must have strong forearms. Is it hard, squeezing like that?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's part of the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotty the guard leans out, tipping his cap, as the Packa pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Late night, Mr. Mannix?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Late night for both of us. Will you call Projection Seven and have’m lace up yesterday’s dailies on “Hail, Cesar!"

dialogues.speaker: SCOTTY
dialogues.text: Sure thing. Yesterday's.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks Scotty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie Mannix sits slumped, hand cupped to forehead, light flickering onto him from the screen. Natalie sits on his side with her clipboard, waiting for his attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onscreen: we pull Baird Whitlock, in his Roman tribune's wardrobe, as he marches angrily up a line of parched and dusty slaves clamoring for water. Baird curses and exclai “Romans before slaves!” as he bats aside those waiting. As he reaches the front of the line our pull back has bro into frame the man giving out water with a dipper. This m whom we see only from behind, wears a simple robe and has perfectly arranged shoulder-length blond hair, slightly w  gl. Baird/Autolochus—once more exclaiming “Roman's before slaves!”—intercepts the dipper which the blond man is handing to a slave. Autolochus is about to drink himself when he takes in the countenance of the blond water-giver Something in the man's face and manner strikes Autolochus mightily. He takes a staggering step backward, in awe. Close on Baird, his face displaying progressive waves of puzzlement, hope, and ineffable wonder. A flash frame and a slate for “Hail, Cesar, Twenty-Seven Baker Two.” Baird steps back into close shot with the dipper again, n displaying waves of puzzlement, ineffable wonder, some aw then back to ineffable wonder. We hear an offscreen “Cut!” but before the flash frame Ba relaxes, his eyeline shifting as he calls out:

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Wuddya think a that one, was that, uh, enough, awe, or—

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, good, maybe a little more wonderment.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: More, you mean more— “Hail Cesar, Twenty-Seven Baker Three.” Baird steps back into frame in awe.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold it, sorry, wait a minute, lemme do it again. He steps forward then immediately steps back into frame i awe. A squinting bit of wonder.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: cut!

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Was that, uh, I don’t know. That one didn’t really have a center.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, no, it was— “Hail Cesar, Twenty-Seven Baker Four.”  92. Baird steps back into frame his face oddly blank.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Hang on. His eyes leave the eyeline. He looks down, arranges his features in an expression of unutterable awe, and then je his look back up to the eyeline, expression locked in pla A long hold, expression steady: unutterable awe. Finally, hissing out of his locked jaw as he maintains th look:

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Howziss. Wuddya hink.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, cut. Eddie, watching. His eyes stay on the screen throughout:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Go ahead, I’m listening. From screen: “Hail Cesar, Twenty-Seven Baker Five.”

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Walt talked to the extra, right guy, no info—doesn’t know where they took Baird, but described the truck they put him in.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: (from screen) Was that, uh, was that—should I get to the wonderment faster?

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Walt found the truck and found the guy who borrowed it from the guy who owns it and is talking to him. From screen: “Hail Cesar, Twenty-Seven Baker Six.” Eddie nods, still looking at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Walt’s a problem-solver, he’s a good man. What else?  93.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: (from screen) Todd, you can—you just look like an imbecile mushed up against the camera, can you—-Sam, Todd can step out, I’1l just take an eyeline at the corner of the matte box. I'll hand the dipper back to, uh, to, uh, camera guy. From screen: “Hail Cesar, Twenty-Seven Baker Seven.”

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: PR just called in their report on Hobie Doyle premier: warm reception.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: (from screen) Was that—I’m sorry, did you see that, I felt like I had some spittle. Maybe Todd should step back in.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Good. Okay. (starts to rise, eyes still on the screen) Not bad, have ‘em use six. Is this six?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An orchestra plays “Every Now and Then.” Carlotta laughs, across a table from: Hobie, hunched forward, very intent on what he is doing, body jiggling. Wider: he has a strand of spaghetti and is doing rope tri with it.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Watchis now... Gittin’ away... He ropes a salt cellar.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh looka there now! His other hand, on the tablecloth, is starting to walk aw on two fingers, affecting nonchalance.  94. Thinking itself safely out of range, the walking hand sta to walk faster.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «+. Oh, she’s a gittin’ away too! He ropes the walking fingers, tripping his hand. Carlotta, unable to talk from laughter, points at Hobie. Hobie ropes the pointing finger, draws her hand toward hi She slaps at his hand with her free hand. He drops the spaghetti to slap her hand in return then plucks the whip spaghetti-end out of the air in rhythm.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This’s why I never order it with meat sauce.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOTTA
dialogues.text: How’d you get into pictures, Hobie?

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Got roped into it! Aw, I’m just kiddin ya, I wrangled fer a while and then they saw I could say a line’r two’n I was Bad Clem or Deppity Number Two or the guy’s buddy fer a coupla years’n then some’n heard me sing’n they made me the guy.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOTTA
dialogues.text: You’re awfully cute.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Aw heck, you ain’t seen the half of it, I’ll show ya cute, just second here—little souvenir from when I was rodeoin’... He has lowered his head to his hand and he fiddles briefl his mouth. He raises his head again, beaming at Carlotta. He has no teeth. His gums, upper and lower, are hideously bare. Carlotta is aghast—and then amused, more than ever. Hobie chuckles as she laughs:  95.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell ya what, I wuzh shteer- brushtin an I went down and the shteer went up’n m’teeth headed off fer easht Texash—Aww here, it’s comin’ round again! He hastily tucks his teeth back in and croons along with orchestra which is just now arriving at the chorus: Every now and then... Carlotta comes in on top:

dialogues.speaker: CARLOTTA
dialogues.text: Every now and then... The two sing together but Hobie suddenly freezes, seeing something. Long-lens point of view: a bulging attaché case bound aro the middle by a shiny black belt. It rests beside a semi- circular booth, half the throw of the restaurant away. Whoever has the case is hidden by his high-backed booth. back is to us: the side of one leg juts out as does one elbow, active as he eats.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Well now, this is interesting. Hobie’s look turns up: Thessaly Thacker stands at his boo

dialogues.speaker: THESSALY THACKER
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you two were friends. Hobie is distracted, his look shifting between her and th hidden man.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Aw heck yeah, we—we just caught my picture, “Lazy O1' Moon,” ‘n I guess we’re—

dialogues.speaker: CARLOTTA
dialogues.text: Yes, we're friends, we’re—

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Well we’re fixin’ t’be friendly, tell you that.  96.

dialogues.speaker: THESSALY THACKER
dialogues.text: That's good: “Fixin’ To Be Friendly” can be my column headline. Finger-quotes and an exaggerated impression of Hobie’s ac set off the reference. Hobie, unoffended, nods.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Well I guess at’d be okay.

dialogues.speaker: THESSALY THACKER
dialogues.text: Have a good evening. As she moves off Hobie and Carlotta exchange a look: how we do? But Hobie’s look keeps returning to the mystery di

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: I mentioned the name of m’picture, I think we’re s’posed to do that. His long-lens point of view: Thessaly Thacker has stopped talk to the hidden man with the attaché case. Brief conversation. Thessaly tips her head back laughing at som pleasantry. Her cackle carries across the room.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Well now, this is interesting. Hobie’s look turns up: it is—impossibly—tThessaly Thacker again. Or, no it isn’t, it’s Thora.

dialogues.speaker: THORA THACKER
dialogues.text: I thought I was getting an exclusive on this.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: What’s that now, ma’am? She is looking off at her cackling sister.

dialogues.speaker: THORA THACKER
dialogues.text: I'd like to know what the hell is going on here.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: We, uhh... like I said, we just saw “Lazy O1' Moon”—

dialogues.speaker: CARLOTTA
dialogues.text: And Hobie and I are fixin t’be friendly!  97. Thora’s baleful look swings onto her. It holds for a long moment. Then a squint:

dialogues.speaker: THORA THACKER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: We're just, uh... His eyes widen: the mystery man is getting up. The man st briefly outside the booth but is turned mostly away from patting at his mouth with a napkin. He angles more toward It is Burt Gurney. He finishes patting his mouth, tosses the napkin onto the table. His face, so boyish when performing, is now a hard mask. He stoops to pick up the attaché case. A brief look aroun the restaurant, and he heads off. Hobie hastily shuffles himself out of his booth:

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah gotta skedaddle. So sorry! (to Carlotta) Have to catch one a yer pictures next time—lookin’ ford to it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobie exits the club just in time to see the passing-by vehicle of Burt Gurney. Hobie hurries to his car and driver waiting curbside.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Toss me them keys, pard—I'm takin' the car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide on Eddie behind his desk, half-in, half-out of a poo desktop lamplight. He sits hunched, forearms on knees. An insert: on the desk is a letter, its copy too small to read. But we see its letterhead: Lockheed. Back to Eddie, but our angle now swung around so that the desk does not hide his lower body.  98. The hands draped across his knees hold a rosary. EXT. HOLLYWOOD / INT. HOBIE’S CAR - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of neon: “The Garden of Allah,” restaurants, clubs, chase lights around movie-theater marquees. Dissolving in out under the Hollywood Boulevard imagery is the same set of Hobie driving, squinting, eyes fixed on tail lights in front of him. Also dissolving in and out:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE MANNIX WALKING
dialogues.text: Not his purposeful daytime stride but a contemplative str his hands clasped Churchillianly behind his back. He pass through the half-struck columns of the temple of the mone lenders; through the courtyard of Sestimus Amydias, its fountain now giving only spare, echoing drips; and finall through a set we have not yet seen: the road to Calvary, long line of crucifixes looming empty. The montage which connects the two men ends with a dissol full up on Hobie, still driving, but no more city lights reflected in his windshield. We are out, remote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His point-of-view: tail lights of the car well ahead—the only car in sight. Its headlights briefly show us the “Ru Fish Shack” sign on the right. The car turns left. Hobie slows as he approaches the turn.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH FROM BLUFF
dialogues.text: The octahedral house glows below. Burt’s car is parked. Hobie’s car eases up.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: For the first time the house has no interior noise, no yapping dog. We hear only the muffled pounding of surf.  99. The front door clicks, and creaks open. Hobie enters cautiously, looking around at the quiet as h walks toward the lens to stop in close shot, gaping now, surprised at what he sees. Reverse on the living room. Baird Whitlock is alone, a sm figure in the big room, still in Roman wardrobe, a copy o Soviet Life open on his lap, martini glass in hand. He ga at Hobie in mirroring surprise. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Hobie Doyle? You’re a Communist too? Hobie looks around, looks back at Baird. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: So it’s Commies.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Y’ever been in this place? Pretty nice, huh? Just found out it’s Burt Gurney’s! Hobie is not really interested. He looks around a bit mor trying to make sense of it all.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: You here alone?

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Everyone else went down to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Well, all right pard: let’s us head on back to town. You got Mr. Mannix worried sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Communist writers man both sides of a longboat, glove on, pulling hard at the oars. Burt Gurney stands in the prow gazing forward, rather lik George Washington crossing the Delaware but with a yappin dog in the crook of one arm.  100. Now his look turns to one side. His point-of-view: his beach house is coming into view fr behind one of a pair of jagged rocks between us and shore

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: Easy... The writers row more slowly as the house centers up betwe the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: BURT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here! The writers back-paddle to stop the boat. It settles so a show the house perfectly centered between the two snaggle rocks. Satisfied with the boat’s position, Burt Gurney looks abo the vast and empty sea. He looks at his watch: midnight. A writer occasionally dips an oar for a short front- or b stroke, keeping the boat in position. The boat dips and b water slapping on wood. An occasional yap from the dog. Long beat. A huge roar. Seething water. Ocean surface just by the longboat roils mightily—and is breached. A huge black column rises, rises, rises from the sea. The writers give voice to an awed “Oh...” The column stops rising. The roaring of great engines, and the angry hiss of water streaming from the column, subsides to... near-silence. J the gentle chug of idling engines and the faint bleep. bl bleep. of sonar. Waves slosh feebly against the imposing black column: the conning tower of a submarine. The metallic screek-screek-screek of a hatch being opened The sound moves the dog to more yapping. Burt Gurney hands the dog to one of the forward writers. BURT (CONT’D) Take care of him.  101. He leaps from the longboat to the sub, grabbing brackets in a vertical line up its side: a ladder. Before he can climb, though, writers’ voices exclaim “Tell him!” “Give to him!” “Give the speech!” HERMAN’S VOICE Comrade! Burt turns, twisting from the ladder to look back a the longboat. Herman rises in front. A ripple of motion goes through th writers behind him: something is being passed forward.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN
dialogues.text: Comrade: we salute you! You are going to Moscow to become Soviet Man and help forge the future. We stay behind, continuing to serve in our disguise as capitalist handmaidens. Looks around, uncertain, and gets encouraging nods from t other writers.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But the money should go to the cause, not to the servants of the cause. A chorus of ‘hear, hear’s from the writers as he gropes f finish.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We—well, we... The passed-forward object arrives at the man immediately behind Herman who now gives Herman a nudge. He turns to t the object, and turns back holding it out toward Burt. It is the attaché case cinched by black belt.

dialogues.speaker: HERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Our modest contribution to the Comintern. He tosses it, and Burt, with one hand anchoring him to th ladder, one-handedly catches. He looks at the case, noddi deep appreciation for what it represents. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: BURT
dialogues.text: They will be pleased.  102. The dog, whining and writhing in discontent in the arms o the writer in charge of him, finally breaks free and leap yapping toward his master. Burt reflexively drops the case to grab the arriving dog. The case hits the water and dipsy-doodles down, down, dow into murkiness. The writers give a unison dismayed “Oh...” Burt Gurney, angled out from the ladder, gazes down at th spot where the case is disappearing. A long looking beat. Finally, a small arch of his eyebrow—his only comment on life’s unpredictability. He swings his body back in again the sub and climbs one-handed, holding the dog. A man wearing a sable cap waits at the top. When Burt arr the waiting man hands him a sable cap. Burt puts it on an gazes down at the longboat. BURT (CONT’D) Professor! Will you join me? Marcuse, near the back of the boat, gestures faintly with pipe.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUSE
dialogues.text: No. I will work from within. Burt nods concession. The man behind Burt stoops to open hatch and both men climb in. On the writers, watching. The roar of engines, the seething hiss of water. The sub descends. The writers fight their oars to keep the longboat steady the bucking sea. The sub disappears. The sloshes diminish. The black sea r on in peace restored. After a quiet beat:

dialogues.speaker: WRITER
dialogues.text: Well, it’s late. And I have revisions.  103. INT. HOBIE’S CAR - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE AND BAIRD
dialogues.text: In Hobie’s car they make the right turn from the beach ac road to head south on the coast highway. Hobie hums “Lazy Moon" as he drives; Baird gazes placidly out. Baird is struck by a thought. He looks at his watch, winc

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Late. I am in the doghouse. Hobie glances at him as Baird thinks.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Know what, better forget my place. Drop me at the Beverly Hills Hotel—that okay?

dialogues.speaker: HOBIE
dialogues.text: Sure. Both men look, attention drawn by sirens: an oncoming lin police vehicles, their rooflights spinning. The cars whoosh past. Baird turns to track them and Hobie looks in his rear-vie The vehicles skid into a left turn at the “Fish Shack” si Baird faces forward again. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Huh!

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: FADE IN SOUND: Morning birds, intermittent car-bys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE IN PICTURE: Studio gate. We are looking across the street at the main gate. There little traffic at this early hour. A cab pulls up and sto curbside. Its passenger gets out.  104. The cab pulls away and we see the discharged passenger: B Whitlock. Still in breastplate and leather skirt, he saun toward the walk-through by the guard shack, whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We track laterally with an Assistant Director who, intent a clipboard, slowly walks past a foreground crucifix, the occupant of which, facing away from us, is in frame only the extent of his two crossed feet. The A.D., still study his clipboard, slows to a halt just as we bring another crucifix into the foreground. Its occupant too we see onl from the ankles down. The A.D. now looks up from the list on his clipboard to t unseen man on the foreground crucifix. A.D. Who’re you?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Todd. The A.D. looks down his list. He shakes his head, still unclear; he looks back up. A.D. Do you get a hot breakfast or a box breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The A.D. rolls his eyes. A.D. Are you a principal or an extra? Beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I think I’m a principal. INT. EDDIE’S OFFICE - DAY Baird, in wardrobe, is in the chair in front of Eddie’s d with his legs crossed, hands clasped behind his head, the picture of cheerfulness.  105.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: So I’m thinkin’, “What the hell! I’ve woken up in strange houses before but never without a broad next to me!” Eddie glares.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (tight) Uh-huh. Baird, oblivious, thinks he has an audience.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: These guys were pretty interesting, though. They've actually figured out the laws that dictate, well—everything, history, sociology, politics, morality. Everything. It's all in a book called “Kapital.”

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: That right.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. With a K. And you’re not gonna believe this, but it even explains the stuff we do here at the studio. Because the studio is actually nothing more than an instrument of capitalism!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: So it blindly follows these laws just like any other institution, the laws that these guys’ve figured out. The studio makes pictures to serve the system, that’s its function, that’s really what we're all up to, here.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Is it. Eddie rises from behind his desk and advances on Baird, w prattles on.  Eddie has his feet. Slap! 106.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're just confirming what they call the “status quo.” I mean, we might tell ourselves we're “creating” something of artistic value, that there’s some kinda spiritual dimension to the picture business, but what it is, is this fat cat Nick Schenk out in New York running a factory that makes these lollypops to pacify the—wWHOOF! grabbed Baird by the breastplate and hauled him to He now slaps him, forehand and backhand: Slap! BAIRD (CONT’D) What th— Eddie pulls him chest-to-chest and holds him there so tha may stare straight into his eyes as the words pour out:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Now you listen to me, buster: Nick Schenk and this studio have been good to you and to everyone else who works here. If I ever hear you badmouthing Mr. Schenk again it’1l be the last thing you say before I have you tossed into jail for colluding in your own abduction.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: But Eddie, I didn’t— Slap! Slap!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Shaddup. You’re gonna go out there and you're gonna finish “HAIL, CESAR!" You're gonna give that speech at the feet of the penitent thief and you’re gonna believe every word you say. Slap! Slap!

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're gonna do it because you’re an actor and that’s what you do. Just like the director does what he does, and the writer and the script girl and the guy who claps the slate. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're gonna do it because the picture has worth and you have worth if you serve the picture and you’re never gonna forget that again.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: (blubbering) Okay Eddie, I won’t forget it. The manhandling and Eddie’s harsh tone have brought Baird tears. Eddie releases his fistful of Romanwear with a sho that sends Baird staggering backward.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: You're damn right you won’t. Not as long as I run this dump. Baird nods, whimpering, as he retreats to the door.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Okay, Eddie. Eddie reseats himself behind his desk. Baird is reaching the doorknob but Eddie stops him with a sharp:

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Baird! Baird turns, sniveling, his hand on the knob. Eddie smiles, points at him, and gives a tight nod: EDDIE (CONT’D) Go out there and be a star! It heartens Baird. He wipes his eyes with some tunic-slee and even manages a tremulous smile back at Eddie and a re nod.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE WALKING
dialogues.text: He walks purposefully across the lot. Natalie is deep beh trotting to catch up, arms full of a flower arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Mannix! He turns, waits.  108.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Since you’re going to your car, thought you might want to take this.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: From DeeAnna Moran. Thank you, and she doesn’t need to adopt her baby after all.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: She asked Joe Silverman out for dinner last night, I guess it went well, they drove to Palm Springs and were married at three this morning.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Will you be gone long? Today’s list to go through.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Less than an hour, personal errand. (down at the flowers he holds) Nice arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: She charged it to the studio.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Right. He turns from her to proceed but immediately stops with a surprised “Gah!”

dialogues.speaker: THORA THACKER
dialogues.text: Just coming to see you.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Good morning. Sorry about last night, Thora—didn’t know your sister would show up.  109.

dialogues.speaker: THORA THACKER
dialogues.text: Well, that’s as may be, but I certainly learned my lesson. Whatever you say today, Eddie Mannix, my column tomorrow is about—"On Wings as Eagles.”

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Thora, I wouldn’t do that if I were you. Thora smiles thinly.

dialogues.speaker: THORA THACKER
dialogues.text: I’m sure you wouldn’t.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No no, you don’t understand. (looks around) Let’s sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thora and Eddie seat themselves at a curved stone bench beneath a stone table upon which Eddie puts the flowers. Behind them is a building that says WARDROBE. A Roman centurion sits against its exterior wall lacing up his sandals’ calf straps. Others emerge from the building one a time, each cinching up the chin strap on his bristle-to helmet or giving the bottom of his breastplate a tug or i some other way making ready.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I’m telling you not to run the column, Thora, for your own good. A hoot from Thora.

dialogues.speaker: THORA THACKER
dialogues.text: I can judge my own interest. This will be the story of the year—and it so happens the Hearst Syndicate is looking to pick up a Hollywood column. Hearst is four million readers. And if I get them—tThessaly doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: And you think this'll cinch it for you.  110.

dialogues.speaker: THORA THACKER
dialogues.text: You know it will! Baird Whitlock, your biggest star, got his first major part—in “On Wings as Eagles"—by engaging in sodomy with the picture’s director, Laurence Laurentz. She wears a smug smile, awaiting protestation. Eddie only nods, equably.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: We've all heard the story. But here’s something you haven’t heard: your source is a Communist. If you print it, it’ll be dismissed as a Commie smear tactic—and you'll be dismissed as a Commie stooge. Her smile starts to fade. EDDIE (CONT’D) Burt Gurney has left the country and the cell he was part of has been smashed by the police. You might’ve thought he was credible because he’s Mr. Laurentz’s current... protegé, but—you don’t want to be seen as Burt Gurney’s mouthpiece after this. Thora’s look curdles. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: THORA THACKER
dialogues.text: How did you know Burt was my source?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Talked to Laurence late last night, put two and two together. (rises, indicating flowers) Well, no need to send this since I ran into you. It’s by way of apology for Thessaly horning in last night. I do value our friendship, Thora— (looks at watch) —but I'm late for something important.  111.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light wipes onto Eddie, rosary in hand.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Bless me, Father, for I have sinned.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: How long since your last confession, my son?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: It’s been, uh... (looks at watch) What, twenty-seven hours?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: It’s too often, my son. You’re really not that bad. Eddie grimly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Father. I snuck another cigarette. Or two. I didn’t make it home in time for dinner. And I, uh... I struck a movie star in anger. A sigh from the unseen priest.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: All right. Five Hail Marys.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. Father... Eddie is struggling.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes my son?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: May I ask you something, Father?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Of course, my son.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: If there’s something that’s easy... is that wrong?  Silence. Then: 112.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Easy?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Easy to do, easy to—an easy job—not a bad job, it’s not bad. But then there’s another job, that’s... that’s not so easy. In fact it’s hard. It’s so hard, Father, sometimes I don’t know if I can keep doing it. But it seems right. I don’t know how to explain.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: God wants us to do what’s right.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah... (thinking, nodding) Yeah, course He does.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: The inner voice that tells you it’s right—it comes from God, my son. Eddie glances at his watch again.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, got it.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: It’s His way of saying that—

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: (rising) Yeah yeah, I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autolochus is gazing up and off-camera as we pull him thr a crowd of Israelites, his face transfigured in wondermen As he reaches the front of the crowd he sinks to his knee The camera pulls up and away to frame him before three crucifixes on the mount. Gracchus, familiar from our epic’s first scene, approache  113.

dialogues.speaker: GRACCHUS
dialogues.text: Why on your knees before this Hebrew, Autolochus? Baird rises, turning his attention to his friend and plac a comradely hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOLOCHUS
dialogues.text: I encountered him before, Gracchus, beside the well of Jehosaphat. And what manner of man! Gracchus doesn’t understand:

dialogues.speaker: GRACCHUS
dialogues.text: He is a priest of the Israelites, despised even by the other priests.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOLOCHUS
dialogues.text: No. On yesterday’s march, punished by the dust of the road, I sought to drink first at the well—before the slaves in my charge, whose thirst was greater than my own.

dialogues.speaker: GRACCHUS
dialogues.text: (uncomprehending) A Roman drinks before a slave.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOLOCHUS
dialogues.text: This man was giving water to all. He saw no Romans, no slaves. He saw only men—weak men—and gave succour. He saw suffering, which he sought to ease. He saw sin, and gave love.

dialogues.speaker: GRACCHUS
dialogues.text: “Love,” Autolochus?

dialogues.speaker: AUTOLOCHUS
dialogues.text: He saw my own sin, and greed, and thirst, Gracchus. But in his eyes I saw no shadow of reproach. I saw only light. The light of God.

dialogues.speaker: GRACCHUS
dialogues.text: You mean, of the gods. Autolochus gravely shakes his head.  Gracchus, 114.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOLOCHUS
dialogues.text: I do not, friend Gracchus. This Hebrew is son of the one God, the God of this far-flung tribe. And why shouldn't God's anointed appear here, among these strange people, in this strange place? Here, Gracchus, in this sundrenched land. Why should he not take this form—the form of an ordinary man? A man bringing us not the old truths, but a new one. is willing to believe, but is confused.

dialogues.speaker: GRACCHUS
dialogues.text: A new truth?

dialogues.speaker: AUTOLOCHUS
dialogues.text: A truth beyond the truth that we can see. A truth beyond this world, a truth told not in words but in light. Gracchus’s chin crimps as he juts his jaw, absorbing this message. A truth we can see if we have but... Autolochus is staring at Gracchus. His eyes slowly narrow a squint. His jaw drops open as he stares. After a beat of fixed staring: AUTOLOCHUS (CONT’D) -.. if we have but—but—

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: CUT. Cut. Faith. Have but faith.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Faith! Faith? Not, um—

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: No, they changed it.

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Goddamnit. Sorry, I’1l get it, don’t worry.

dialogues.speaker: GRACCHUS
dialogues.text: Could I get a pat down, I’m sweating like a pig.  115.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE MANNIX AND NATALIE
dialogues.text: They stride across the lot, Natalie following Eddie with notepad as at the beginning of the movie.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Gloria DeLamour checked herself out of Our Lady of Perpetual Rest and showed up for work in good shape.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Nn.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Still raining in Gallup, New Mexico, and the “Tucumcari!” crew has shot all the plates we need for “Came the Rain.”

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Then—just shoot the showdown in the weather and we'll retitle it “Tucumcari Tempest” “Desert Squall” “Hold Back the Storm”... He momentarily casts about.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE-OVER
dialogues.text: The stories begin. The stories end.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: I dunno—bounce it off the writers.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE-OVER
dialogues.text: So it has been.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Check. Here’s today’s call list. She hands a sheet forward. He studies it, hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Add a call to a Mr. Cuddahy at the Lockheed Corporation.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Long call, short?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: “Thanks but no thanks”—how long was that?  116.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE-OVER
dialogues.text: But the story of Eddie Mannix—

dialogues.speaker: NATALIE
dialogues.text: Check. Who do we call first?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE-OVER
dialogues.text: —will never end. Eddie pushes back a sleeve to look at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: New York first. Time to check in with Mr. Schenk.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE-OVER
dialogues.text: For his is a tale written... in light everlasting. As they head up the walk to the administration building w boom up to bring into view the skyline of the lot beyond. the middle distance is the Capitol Pictures water tower, word painted on its face: BEHOLD. A slanting sun, hidden by clouds, sends down golden beams
